newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Government finds interpreters' rules illegal.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Government finds interpreters' rules illegal.

text.p: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission Friday ruled the International Association of Conference Interpreters of Geneva, Switzerland, has been illegally fixing prices.
The American commission has jurisdiction because the 2,500 member association, known by its French aroncym AIIC, has 140 U.S. affiliate members. The AIIC has members in 68 countries.

"We conclude there was an unlawful agreement among AIIC members as to the minimum price to be charged for conference interpretation in the U.S.," wrote FTC Commissioner Christine Varney, writing for all five commissioners.

The decision said the AIIC must eliminate rules on fees, travel expenses, pro bono work and commissions. It also said the association could not prevent interpreters with permanent jobs from doing freelance work.
IIC rules that interpreter team size and other non-price items were not found to be illegal.
AIIC is a voluntary professional association of interpreters who interpret at multilingual conferences and other high-level meetings.
